curriculum.title: Explorations in Ancient Greek Philosophy
curriculum.description: A comprehensive examination of the foundational texts and ideas of Ancient Greek philosophers, focusing on ethics, epistemology, and political philosophy. Students will engage in critical discussions and thought experiments to deepen their understanding of philosophical concepts and their relevance today.

weeks.topic: Introduction to Philosophy and Socratic Method
weeks.description: Overview of philosophy and the Socratic method. Introduction to key philosophical questions.
weeks.assignment: Reflect on a personal belief and explore its justification.

weeks.description: Discussion on Socratic ethics and the relationship between knowledge and virtue.
weeks.assignment: Write a dialogue exploring a moral dilemma.

weeks.description: Investigate Plato's Theory of Forms and its implications for knowledge and reality.
weeks.assignment: Create an argument for or against the existence of abstract forms.

weeks.description: Explore Aristotle's concepts of substance, essence, and his critique of Plato's forms.
weeks.assignment: Compare Aristotle's and Plato's views on reality.

weeks.description: Examine Aristotle's virtue ethics and the concept of the 'Golden Mean'.
weeks.assignment: Identify a contemporary ethical issue and apply Aristotle's ethics.

weeks.description: Compare and contrast the ethical systems of Epicureanism and Stoicism.
weeks.assignment: Analyze how each philosophy addresses the concept of happiness.

weeks.description: Investigate the Sophists' views on truth and morality, and their influence on rhetoric.
weeks.assignment: Debate the merits and pitfalls of relativism.

weeks.description: Analysis of Plato's ideal state and the role of the philosopher-king.
weeks.assignment: Design a modern political system inspired by Plato's ideas.

weeks.description: Study Aristotle's views on governance and the nature of the state.
weeks.assignment: Evaluate a contemporary political system through Aristotle's lens.

weeks.description: Explore the development of ethical thought during the Hellenistic period, including Cynicism and Skepticism.
weeks.assignment: Write a reflection on the relevance of Cynic principles today.

weeks.description: Analyze the allegory of the cave and its implications for knowledge and enlightenment.
weeks.assignment: Create a modern allegory that illustrates a similar theme.

weeks.description: Delve into the relationship between metaphysics and epistemology in the works of Plato and Aristotle.
weeks.assignment: Discuss how each philosopher defines knowledge.

weeks.description: Explore how ancient philosophers viewed language and its relation to thought.
weeks.assignment: Examine a language issue through the lens of these texts.

weeks.topic: The Legacy of Ancient Greek Philosophy
weeks.description: Assess the impact of Greek philosophy on later philosophical traditions.
readings: Selected excerpts from later philosophers influenced by Greek thought
weeks.assignment: Present on a philosopher influenced by Greek philosophy.

weeks.description: Engage in a final discussion synthesizing course themes and personal growth in philosophical thinking.
weeks.assignment: Submit a reflective essay on your philosophical journey this semester.
